text: it's Thailand's pot of gold that keeps
on giving
tourism has continued to grow through
political and economic upheavals it
accounts for more than seven percent of
the entire economy visitor numbers were
up 20 percent last year until December
then a sudden drop as anti-government
protests continued in Bangkok
week after week growing bolder able to
challenge and at times chase off the
police no one can guess now how this
will end so will people still want to
spend their holidays here until now the
protests have been little more than an
occasional inconvenience to tourists
sometimes even unexpected attraction but
the total shutdown planned for next week
will have a far more serious impact on
the city's economy
what's more worrying is this country's
steady drift into a more violent and
protracted conflict that could drive the
much bigger investors of manufacturing
to reconsider their commitment to
Thailand electronics for example worth
20 billion dollars a year more than a
quarter of the exports that Thailand
depends on heavily these are big
long-term investments they're not easy
to move elsewhere but if they do they
won't come back quickly
outside Bangkok the turmoil is scarcely
visible
there's no reason yet to avoid
Thailand's beach resorts but even they
can't be completely insulated from an
intractable conflict which threatens to
tear this country in half Jonathan had
BBC news Bangkok
